description: TO POSTPONE INDEFINITELY THE H. J. RESOLUTION PROVIDING THAT THE PRESIDENT OF THE SENATE AND THE SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE BE DIRECTED TO ADJOURN THEIR RESPECTIVE HOUSES FROM SATURDAY DEC. 22ND UNTIL WEDNESDAY THE 2ND OF JAN.  (P.565)

TO CONCUR IN AN AMENDMENT TO H. R. 26, (3/9/1822), A BILL PROVIDING FOR THE APPORTIONMENT OF THE HOUSE ACCORDING TO THE FOURTH CENSUS, WHICH AMENDMENT INCREASES THE MEMBERS OF THE HOUSE BY MAKING THE RATIO OF MEMBERSHIP ONE FOR EVERY 42,000 PERSONS IN EAH STATE
TO AMEND H. R. 26, BY FIXING THE RATIO AT ONE REPRESENTATIVE FOR EVERY 45,000 INSTEAD OF 40,000 PEOPLE IN EACH STATE. (P.832)
TO AMEND H. R. 26, BY REDUCING THE RATIO FROM 40,000 TO 39,000 PEOPLE FOR EACH REPRESENTATIVE IN THE HOUSE.  (P.846)
TO AMEND H. R. 26, BY FIXING THE RATIO AT 41,000 PERSONS FOR EACH REPRESENTATIVE.  (P.863)
TO AMEND H. R. 26, BY FIXING THE RATIO AT 38,000 PEOPLE FOR EACH REPRESENTATIVE IN THE HOUSE.  (P.864)
TO AMEND H. R. 26, BY FIXING THE RATIO AT 41,500 PEOPLE FOR EACH REPRESENTATIVE IN THE HOUSE.  (P.874-A)
TO AMEND H. R. 26, BY STRIKING OUT THE RATIO OF 40,000 PER- SONS TO REPRESENTATIVE AND LEAVING BLANK THE NUMBER, TO BE FILLED IN BY A FUTURE MOTION.  (P.874-B)

TO AMEND H. R. 26, BY RECOMMITING IT TO THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE FOR THE PURPOSE OF OBTAINING A SMALLER APPORTIONMENT RATIO OF 40,000 PEOPLE FOR REPRESENTATION BASED ON THE FOURTH CENSUS.  (P.889, 880)
TO AMEND H. R. 26, BY REDUCING BE 4,000 PERSONS THE RATIO FOR APPORTIONMENT OF REPRESENTATION THEREBY MAKING THE NUM- BER 38,000.  (P.890)

TO AMEND H. R. 26, BY PROVIDING THAT THE ELECTION OF REPRE- SENTATIVES SHALL REPRESENT THE SAME NUMBER OF PERSONS AS NEARLY AS MAY BE PRACTICABLE, AGREEABLE TO THE 4TH CENSUS, AND NOT TO DEMINISH THE PRESENT NUMBER OF REPRESENTATIVES FROM ANY ONE STATE. (P.898)
TO RECOMMIT AN AMENDMENT TO H.R. 26 TO A SELECT COMMITTEE WHICH AMENDMENT WOULD MAKE THE RATIO 39,900 INSTEAD OF 42,000.  (P.907)
TO AMEND H. R. 26, BY REDUCING THE RATIO OF REPRESENTATIVES FROM 50,000 TO 42,000 IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE FOURTH CENSUS. (P.925)
TO AMEND H. R. 26, BY CHANGING THE RATIO OF REPRESENTATIVES BY SUBSTITUTING 44,000 IN LIEU OF 50,000.  (P.938)
TO RECOMMIT H. R. 26  TO THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE.  (P.939
TO PASS H. R. 26.  (P.947)

TO AMEND THE SENATE AMENDMENT TO H. R. 26, WHICH AMENDMENT INCLUDES AFTER THE WORD "SESSION", THE WORDS "BY AN ACTUAL ENUMERATION MADE PREVIOUS TO MARCH 3, 1822 IN THE MEASURE PRESCRIBED BY THE ACT PROVIDING FOR TAKING THE 4TH CENSUS". (P.1164, 1167)
TO CONCUR WITH THE REPORT OF THE COMMITTEE ON THE JUDICIARY IN THEIR DISAGREEMENT TO THE AMENDMENT OF THE SENATE TO H. R. 26.  (P.195)

TO CONCUR WITH THE AMENDMENT OF THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE TO H. R. 90, (3/15/1822), A BILL MAKING CERTAIN APPROPRIA- TIONS FOR THE MILITARY ESTABLISHMENT FOR 1822 AND TOWARDS THE SERVICE OF 1823, WHICH AMENDMENT PROVIDES FOR FILLING THE BLANK IN THE FIRT SECTION FOR PAY AND SUBSISTANCE OF OFFICERS OF THE ARMY WITH THE SUM OF $982,917
TO PASS H. R. 90 (3/15/1822), A BILL MAKING AN APPROPRIATION FOR THE SUPPORT OF THE MILITARY ESTABLISHMENT FOR THE YEAR 1822.  (P.1192)
TO CONSIDER A JOINT RESOLUTION PROVIDING TO FIX THE TIME FOR THE ADJOURNMENT OF THE PRESENT SESSION AT THE FIRST MONDAY IN NEXT APRIL.  (P.1250)

TO AMEND H. R. 1, A BILL TO ESTABLISH A UNIFORM SYSTEM OF BANKRUPTCY THROUGHOUT THE U. S., BY PROVIDING FOR ADMITTING OTHERS THAN MERCHANTS TO AVAIL THEMSELVES OF THE BENEFIT OF THE LAW TO ESTABLISH A UNIFORM SYSTEM OF BANKRUPTCY.  (P. 1276)

TO AMEND H. R. 1, BY PROVIDING THAT NO CERTIFICATE OF DIS- CHARGE UNDER THE PROVISIONS OF THE ACT, SHALL OPERATE TO DISCHARGE ANY BANKRUPT FROM ANY DEBT, EXCEPT SUCH AS MAY BE DUE OR OWING TO PERSONS WHO MAY BE LIABLE TO BECOME BANK- RUPT UNDER THE ACT. (P.1277)

TO AMEND H. R. 1, BY PROVIDING THAT ALL CLASSES OF THE COM- MUNITY ARE TO HAVE THE PRIVILEGES AT THEIR ELECTION OF BECOMING VOLUNTARY BANKRUPTS WITH THE CONSENT OF A MAJOR PART IN VALUE OF ALL CREDITORS AND SUCH BANKRUPTS BE SUB- JECTED TO THE SAME PROCEDINGS AS PROVIDED ALL OTHER BANKRUPTS
TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF H. R. 1.  (P.1298)

TO CONCUR IN A REPORT OF THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE IN THEIR AMENDMENT TO THE PETITION CONTESTING THE ELECTION OF JEREMIAH CAUSDEN AS REPRESENTATIVE FROM MARYLAND, WHICH REPORT DENIES THE RIGHT OF GENERAL REED TO THE SEAT HE CLAIMS.  (P.1311, 1312)

TO AGREE TO THE 2ND RESOLUTION AS AMENDED AND REPORTED BY THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE TO THE PETITION RELATING TO THE CONTESTED ELECTION IN MARYLAND; WHICH RESOLUTION PROVIDES THAT PHILIP REED IS NOT ENTITLED TO A SEAT IN THE HOUSE DUE TO AN EVEN VOTE CAS IN THE ELECTION
TO ADOPT THE RESOLUTION THAT PHILIP REED IS ENTITLED TO A SEAT IN THIS HOUSE AS A REPRESENTATIVE OF MARYLAND ; THE RESOLUTION IS THE RESULT OF A PETITION CONTESTING THE MARYLAND ELECTION.  (P.1323)
TO TAKE UP A S. J. RESOLUTION PROPOSING ADJOURNMENT OF THE PRESENT SESSION OF CONGRESS ON THE FIRST MONDAY IN APRIL. (P.1325, 1194)

TO AMEND H. R. 15 (4/17/1822), A BILL AUTHORIZING THE SECRE- TARY OF THE TREASURY TO EXCHANGE CERTAIN STOCKS BEARING AN INTEREST OF FIVE PER CENT PER CERTAIN STOCKS BEARING HIGHER INTEREST BY REDUCING THE SUM FROM 30 TO 26 MILLIONS AND DIRECTING THE BOOK TO BE OPENED FROM MAY 1 TO AUG
TO PASS H. R. 37, AN ACT SUPPLEMENTARY TO THE ACT PROVIDING FOR THE RELIEF OF CERTAIN PERSONS ENGAGED IN THE LAND AND NAVAL SERVICE OF THE U. S. IN THE REVOLUTIONARY WAR.  (P. 1371)

TO AGREE TO THE FIRST RESOLUTION OF THE COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN RELATIONS RECOMMENDING THE RECOGNITION OF THE INDEPENDENCE OF THE SOUTH AMERICAN PROVINCES, AND PROPOSING AN APPROPRI- ATION TO CARRY THE SAME INTO EFFECT.  (P.1382)

TO PASS H. R. 15 (4/17/1822), A BILL AUTHORIZING THE SECRE- TARY OF THE TREASURY TO EXCHANGE CERTAIN STOCKS BEARING AN INTEREST OF FIVE PER CENT PER CERTAIN STOCKS BEARING HIGHER INTEREST.  (P.1330, 1442)

TO RECONSIDER THE VOTE REFUSING PERMISSION TO MR. GARNETT OF VIRGINIA TO INCLUDE IN THE JOURNAL HIS REASONS FOR VOTING AGAINST THE RESOLUTION TO RECOGNIZE THE INDEPENDENCE OF THE SOUTH AMERICAN GOVERNMENTS AND PROPOSING AN APPROPRIATION TO CARRY THE SAMEINTO EFFECT

TO CONCUR IN AN AMENDMENT OF THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE TO H. R. 79 (4/29/1822), A BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE SUPPORT OF THE GOVERNMENT FOR 1822, WHICH AMENDMENT PROVIDES TO STRIKE OUT THE $9,000 APPROPRIATION FOR THE REPAIR OF THE CUMBERLAND ROA
THAT THE USUAL HOUR OF MEETING BE AT ELEVEN O'CLOCK.  SPEAK- ER VOTING NAY.  (P.1538)
TO ORDER A CALL OF THE HOUSE.  (P.1540)
TO DISCHARGE THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE FROM FURTHER CONSI- DERATION OF CERTAIN RESOLUTIONS PROPOSING AN ALTERATION OF THE LAWS LAYING DUTIES ON IMPORTED GOODS.  (P.1547)
TO POSTPONE CONSIDERATION TO THE FIRST MONDAY IN DECEMBER OF CERTAIN RESOLUTIONS PROPOSING AN ALTERATION OF THE LAWS LAYING DUTIES ON IMPORTED GOODS.  (P. 1547)
TO ORDER THE ENGROSSMENT AND 3RD READING OF H. R. 152 (3/4/1822), A BILL FOR THE RELIEF OF OFFICERS AND VOLUNTEERS ENGAGED IN THE SEMINOLE WAR.
TO PASS H. R. 172 (3/4/1822), A BILL TO REPEAL THE ACT TO ENCOURAGE VACCINATION.  (P.1640)
TO DISCHARGE THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE FROM CONSIDERATION OF H. R. 175, A BILL REDUCING THE COMPENSATION OF SENATORS AND REPRESENTATIVES IN CONGRESS.  (P.1648, 1646)
TO AMEND H. R. 175, BY REDUCING THE MILEAGE ALLOWED SENATORS AND REPRESENTATIVES FROM $6.00 FOR EVERY 20 MILES TO $6.00 FOR EVERY 30 MILES.  (P.1651, 1650)
TO RECOMMIT H.R. 175 TO COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE, WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO REPORT TO THE NEXT SESSION OF CONGRESS WHETHER THERE ARE ANY OFFICERS IN THE GOVERNMENT WHOSE SALARIES MAY BE REDUCED.  (P.1652)
TO AMEND H. R. 175, BY REDUCING THE MILEAGE ALLOWED TO SENATORS AND REPRESENTATIVES TO TAKE EFFECT FROM THE FIRST DAY OF LAST JULY.  (P.1652)
TO AMEND H. R. 175, BY POSTPONING OPERATION OF THE BILL TO THE FIRST DAY OF NEXT JULY.  (P.1652)

TO AMEND H. R. 50, A BILL FOR THE PRESERVATION AND REPAIR OF THE CUMBERLAND ROAD, BY AUTHORIZING THE PRESIDENT TO CEDE TO THE STATES OF MARYLAND, VIRGINIA, AND PENNSYLVANIA ALL THE RIGHT AND TITLE OF THE U. S. IN THE ROAD FROM CUMBERLAND TO WHEELING; ANDTHAT THE TERMS INSURE THE PRESERVATION OF THE ROAD AND NO FURTHER COLLECTION OF TOLLS EXCEPT FOR REPAIR
TO AGREE TO AN AMENDMENT MADE IN THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE TO H. R. 50, WHICH AMENDMENT APPROPRIATES $9,000 FOR REPAIR OF THE CUMBERLAND ROAD.  (P.1692)
TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF H. R. 50. (P.1692)
TO CONSIDER H. R. 175, A BILL REDUCING THE COMPENSATION OF SENATORS AND REPRESENTATIVES IN CONGRESS.  (P.1701)
TO POSTPONE CONSIDERATION OF H. R. 175 UNTIL THE FIRST MON- DAY IN DECEMBER.  (P.1711)

TO AMEND H. R. 175, BY INCREASING FROM $4.00 TO $6.00 PER DAY THE AMOUNT ALLOWED MEMBERS FOR ATTENDANCE AND $6.00 FOR EVERY TWENTY MILES FOR THEIR NECESSARY TRAVEL TO AND FROM THE SEAT OF GOVERNMENT.  (P.1721)
TO RECOMMIT H.R. 175 TO THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE AND MAKE IT THE ORDER OF THE DAY.  (P.1722)
TO RECOMMIT H.R. 50 TO COMMITTEE WITH INSTRUCTIONS TO CAUSE TO BE STRICKEN OUT THE SECTION AUTHORIZING THE PRESIDENT TO LESSEN OR INCREASE THE RATES OF THE TOLLS. (P.1734)
TO PASS H. R. 50.  (P.1734)
TO CONSIDER H. R. 175.  (P.1758)

TO RECOMMIT H.R. 175 TO THE COMMITTEE ON RETRENCHMENT WITH INSTRUCTIONS THAT WHEN SAID BILL IS REPORTED TO THE NEXT SESSION OF CONGRESS THE RATE OF MILEAGE BE MADE AT THIRTY INSTEAD OF TWENTY MILES PER DAY FOR THE MEMBERS.  (P.1740, 1758)
TO TABLE H. R. 175.  (P.1760)

TO AMEND H. R. 175, BY REDUCING THE ALLOWANCE OF MEMBERS OF CONGRESS FROM SIX DOLLARS PER DAY FOR ATTENDANCE AND SIX DOLLARS FOR MILAGE, TO FOUR DOLLARS FOR EVERY TWENTY MILES TRAVEL, AND FOUR DOLLARS FOR ATTENDANCE.  (P.1759, 1760)
TO AMEND H. R. 175, BY ALLOWING TO THE MEMBERS OF THE PRE- SENT CONGRESS AN AVERAGE OF SIX DOLLARS PER DAY FOR ATTEN- DANCE, AND SIX DOLLARS FOR MILAGE.  (P.1759)
TO POSPONE CONSIDERATION OF H. R. 175, TO THE SECOND MONDAY IN DECEMBER.  (P.1762)

TO RECOMMIT H. R. 175 TO THE COMMITTEE ON RETRENCHMENT WITH INSTRUCTIONS THAT WHEN SAID BILL IS REPORTED TO THE NEXT SESSION OF CONGRESS, THE RATE OF MILEAGE BE MADE AT THIRTY INSTEAD OF TWENTY MILES PER DAY FOR MEMBERS.  (P.1940, 1958)
TO ADJOURN, DURING DEBATE ON H. R. 175.  (P.1767)

TO CONCUR IN AN AMENDMENT TO H. R. 163 (5/7/1822), A BILL MAKING FURTHER APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE MILITARY SERVICE OF THE U. S. FOR THE YEAR 1822, WHICH AMENDMENT INCLUDES THE APPROPRIATION OF $19,216, FOR THE PAYMENT OF THE EXPENSES INCURRED BY COURT MARTALS IN THE STATE OF NEW YORK
TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF H. R. 163 (5/7/1822), A BILL MAKING FURTHER APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE MILITARY SERVICE FOR 1822.  (P.1785)
TO TABLE S. 9 (APP. 5/7/1822), A BILL FURTHER TO ESTABLISH THE COMPENSATION OF OFFICERS OF THE CUSTOMS AND TO ALTER CERTAIN COLLECTION DISTRICTS.  (P.1869)
TO ORDER THE MAIN QUESTION ON THE ENGROSSMENT AND 3RD READING OF S. 9.  (P.1890, 1550)
TO PASS S. 9.  (P.1871)
TO PASS H. R. 50, OVER THE PRESIDENT'S VETO.  (P.1874)

TO AGREE TO THE FIRST AMENDMENT OF THE SENATE TO H. R. 163, WHICH AMEMDMENT ADDS TO THE APPROPRIATION OF $50,000, FOR FORT CALHOUN, THE WORDS: THIS APPROPRIATION IS NOT TO BE REGARDED AS A CONFIRMATION OF THE CONTRACT MADE WITH ELIZA MIX IN REGARD TO THEFORT

TO AGREE TO THE SECOND AMENDMENT OF THE SENATE TO H. R. 163, WHICH AMENDMENT PROVIDES THAT A SUM NOT EXCEEDING $9,000 BE EXPENDED UNDER THE DIRECTION OF THE PRESIDENT IN REPAIRING THE ROAD FROM CUMBERLAND TO WHEELING.  (P.1896)
TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF H. R. 82, A BILL INCORPORATING THE NAVAL FRATERNAL ASSOCIATION FOR THE RELIEF OF THE FAMILIES OF DECEASED OFFICERS.  (P.542)

TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF H. R. 112 (2/28/1823), A BILL FOR LAYING OUT A ROAD FROM THE LOWER RAPIDS OF THE MIAMI OF LAKE ERIE TO THE WESTERN BOUNDARY OF THE CONNECTICUT WEST RESERVE, IN THE STATE OF OHIO.
TO TABLE H. R. 19, A BILL PROVIDING FOR PROCURING THE NECES- SARY SURVEYS AND ESTIMATES FOR CERTAIN ROADS AND CANALS. (P.625)
TO ENGROSS AND ORDER A THIRD READING OF H. R. 231 (3/3/1823) A BILL FOR THE BETTER ORGANIZATION OF THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE U. S. WITHIN LOUISIANA.  (P.635)

TO STRIKE OUT THE INSTRUCTIONS FROM THE MOTION TO RECOMMIT TO THE COMMITTEE ON THE JUDICIARY H. R. 231, WHICH INSTRUC- TIONS AMEND THE BILL BY AUTHORIZING THE DISTRICT JUDGE OF THE U. S. FOR THE STATE OF LOUISIANA, TO HOLD SPECIAL SES- SIONS IN ADDITION O THE TERMS OF SAID COURT, FOR TRIAL OF CRIMINAL CAUSES, WHENEVER HE MAY DEEM IT EXPEDIENT.
TO AMEND H. R. 231, BY ELIMINATING FROM THE BILL THE PRO- POSED ADDITIONAL COMPENSATION OF $500.00 PER ANNUM TO THE JUDGE OF THE DISTRICT COURT OF THE U. S. IN THE STATE OF LOUISIANA.  (P.689)
TO CONSIDER H. R. 47, A BILL PROVIDING FOR THE OCCUPATION OF THE MOUTH OF THE COLUMBIA.  (P.700)
TO CONSIDER H. R. 19.  (P.700)
TO CONSIDER H. R. 19.  (P.725)

TO PASS H. R. 207 (1/1/1823), A BILL SUPPLEMENTING THE REVOLUTIONARY PENSIONS ACT BY PROVIDING FOR CERTAIN PERSONS ENGAGED IN THE LAND AND NAVAL SERVICE OF THE U. S. IN THE REVOLUTIONARY WAR.  (P.735)
TO TABLE MOTION TO ADJOURN AT 11 O'CLOCK DAILY.

TO TABLE THE RESOLUTION THAT A COMMITTEE BE APPOINTED TO AS- CERTAIN BY WHOM THE SUPPRESSION OF THE PARAGRAPH IN THE LETTER OF WILLIAM R. DICKINSON, CASHIER OF THE BANK OF STUBENVILLE, TO SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY, COMMUNICATED TO THIS HOUSE AT THE LAST ESSION, WAS CAUSED, WITH LEAVE TO SIT DURING THE SESSIONS OF THIS HOUSE.
TO DISCHARGE THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE FROM FURTHER CONSI- DERATION OF H. R. 222, A BILL FOR THE MORE EFFECTIVE PROTEC- TION OF DOMESTIC MANUFACTURE.  (P.1016)
TO PASS S. 14 (2/21/1823), A BILL TO EXTEND THE CHARTER OF THE MECHANICS BANK OF ALEXANDRIA.  (P.1024, 1062)

TO AMEND S. 16 (2/28/1823), A BILL FOR THE PRESERVATION AND REPAIR OF THE CUMBERLAND ROAD TO WHEELING, BY PROVIDING THAT ANY RIGHT WHICH THE U. S. MAY HAVE TO SO MUCH OF THE ROAD AS LIES WITHIN THE STATES OF MARYLAND, PENNSYLVANIA, AND VIRGINIA, IS CEDEDTO EACH STATE, FROM THE FIRST DAY OF DECEMBER NEXT, PROVIDED THE STATE LEGISLATURE ACCEPT THE SAME WITHIN SIX MONTHS, KEEP THE ROAD IN REPAIR, AND COLLECT TOLLS TO DEFRAY THE EXPENSES
TO ORDER THE ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF S. 16 (2/28/1823), A BILL FOR THE PRESERVATION AND REPAIR OF THE CUMBERLAND ROAD.  (P.1074)
TO ORDER THE ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF H. R. 309, A BILL ABOLISHING THE OFFICE OF MEASURES IN THE SEVERAL PORTS OF ENTRY IN THE U. S.  (P.1093)

TO CONCUR IN THE AMENDMENT TO H. R. 265 (3/3/1823), A BILL MAKING FURTHER APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE MILITARY SERVICE OF THE U. S. FOR 1823; WHICH AMENDMENT APPROPRIATES $50,000 FOR THE EXTINCTION OF THE INDIAN TITLE TO CERTAIN RESERVATIONS OF LAND IN GEORGI, MADE UNDER THE TREATIES OF 1817, 1819, AND 1821

TO CONCUR IN AMENDMENT TO H. R. 265, REPORTED FROM THE COM- MITTEE OF THE WHOLE TO ADD TO THE 1ST SECTION OF THE BILL AN APPROPRIATION OF $20,000.00 FOR THE PURCHASE OF SMALL ARMS FOR ARMING THE WHOLE BODY OF THE MILITA IN ADDITION TO THE ANNUAL APPROPRITION OF THE YEAR 1823.

TO CONCUR IN AN AMENDMENT FROM THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE TO H. R. 294 (3/3/1823), A BILL MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE PUBLIC BUILDINGS, WHICH AMENDMENT PROVIDES TO FILL THE BLANK IN THE ITEM FOR FINISHING THE PORTICO TO THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSE WITH THE SM OF $19,000.00.

TO CONCUR IN AN AMENDMENT TO HOUSE BILL SUPPLEMENTING THE ACT TO PROVIDE FOR CERTAIN PERSONS ENGAGED IN THE LAND AND NAVAL SERVICE OF THE U. S. IN THE REVOLUTIONARY WAR; WHICH AMENDMENT ADDS A 4TH SECTION PROVI- DING THAT EVERY PENSION WHICH MAY BECOME PYABLE FROM AND AFTER THE 4TH DAY OF SEPTEMBER NEXT BE REDUCED 20 PERCENT ON THE AMOUNT PAYABLE BY LAW

TO TABLE THE RESOLUTION REQUESTING THE PRESIDENT TO NEGOTI- ATE WITH THE SEVERAL MARITIME POWERS OF EUROPE AND AMERICAN FOR THE EFFECTUAL ABOLITION OF THE AFRICAN SLAVE TRADE; AND ITS ULTIMATE DENUNCIATION, AS PIRACY UNDER THE LAWS OF NAT- IONS, BY CONSET OF THE CIVILIZED WORLD.

TO ADOPT THE RESOLUTION REQUESTING THE PRESIDENT TO NEGOTI- ATE WITH THE SEVERAL MARITIME POWERS OF EUROPE AND AMERICA FOR THE EFFECTUAL ABOLITION OF THE AFRICAN SLAVE TRADE; AND ITS ULTIMATE DENUNCIATION, AS PIRACY UNDER THE LAWS OF NATIONS, BY CONSENT F THE CIVILIZED WORLD
TO CONCUR IN THE 2ND AMENDMENT TO H. R. 265, WHICH AMENDMENT PROVIDES $50,000 FOR THE PURCHASE OF CERTAIN TRACTS OF LAND IN GEORGIA, RESERVED TO THE INDIANS.  (P.1168)
